title: How to Put On a Hijab

steps.title: Choose a square-shaped scarf.
steps.content: Choose a square-shaped scarf. This method works well with a lightweight, square-shaped scarf made from any type of fabric. Choose a light satin or cotton fabric works well in the summer, and a heavier wool fabric is warm for winter. You will also need two scarf pins.

steps.title: Fold the top right corner to the bottom left corner.
steps.content: Fold the top right corner to the bottom left corner. The folded scarf is now shaped like a triangle. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Place the scarf over your head.
steps.content: Place the scarf over your head. The widest part of the triangle should fall at the top of your forehead, with the two corners draped over your shoulders. The third corner of the triangle is at the back of your head. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Pinch the edges of the scarf under your chin.
steps.content: Pinch the edges of the scarf under your chin. Open your mouth to form an "O" while doing this, so your jaw will have room to move around once the hijab is in place. Pin the scarf under your chin.

steps.title: Cross the corners of the scarf over your neck.
steps.content: Cross the corners of the scarf over your neck. Cross the left side to the right, and the right side to the left. Drape the tails over your shoulders.

steps.title: Pin the tails of the scarf behind your head.
steps.content: Pin the tails of the scarf behind your head. Lift up the back corner of the scarf and pin the ends at the back of your head, then drape the corner over the pinned part.

steps.title: Adjust as needed.
steps.content: Adjust as needed. Make sure the scarf is straight and securely in place.

steps.title: Choose a rectangular scarf.
steps.content: Choose a rectangular scarf. A pashmina or another large rectangular scarf works well here. You will also need one pin.

steps.title: Drape it over your head.
steps.content: Drape it over your head. The edge of the scarf should pass over the top of your forehead, with the sides draping over your shoulders. Adjust the scarf so that one side hangs down twice as low as the other.

steps.title: Wrap the long end of the scarf around your chin and over your head.
steps.content: Wrap the long end of the scarf around your chin and over your head. Drape the end of the scarf over your opposite shoulder. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Pin the end in place on the side of your head.
steps.content: Pin the end in place on the side of your head. Use a scarf pin to keep the scarf in place. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Adjust the scarf as needed.
steps.content: Adjust the scarf as needed. The scarf should look as though it forms one long, flowing loop around your head and under your chin. Make sure it's secure and won't slip off.

steps.title: Choose a one or two-piece Al-Amira scarf.
steps.content: Choose a one or two-piece Al-Amira scarf. The one-piece version is made with a hole in the middle, so you can easily slip it over your head. The two piece version also includes an underscarf for extra coverage on your head.

steps.title: Place the underscarf on your head.
steps.content: Place the underscarf on your head. Put it on like you would a headband. It should sit over your forehead, to provide extra coverage there. If you have a one-piece version, you can skip this step.

steps.title: Slide your head through the opening of the scarf.
steps.content: Slide your head through the opening of the scarf. Arrange it so that your face is encircled by the scarf, with its folds draping over your shoulders, chest and back. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Arrange the folds in a comfortable fashion.
steps.content: Arrange the folds in a comfortable fashion. Make sure it's securely in place and won't fall off.
